countermeasure.name: Utilize the Shared Folders tool to monitor active sessions and open files on FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Use the Shared Folders tool on AWS FSx for Windows File Server to monitor active user sessions and open files. This enables you to detect unauthorized access, manage user sessions effectively, and ensure proper resource utilization. Monitoring active sessions and open files helps prevent prolonged unauthorized access and minimizes the risk of data breaches or misuse.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Access the Shared Folders Tool: Open the Shared Folders tool on your FSx for Windows File Server through the File and Storage Services in Windows Server Manager or via Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) session.
  2. Monitor Active Sessions: Regularly check the "Sessions" tab to view currently connected users and their access details. Look for any unusual or unauthorized sessions that may indicate potential security risks.
  3. Review Open Files: Navigate to the "Open Files" tab to see all files currently in use by active sessions. Monitor for any unexpected or unauthorized access to sensitive files.
  4. Terminate Unauthorized Access: If unauthorized sessions or file accesses are detected, use the Shared Folders tool to immediately disconnect the session or close open files to prevent further access.
  5. Log and Audit Activities: Keep logs of session and file access activities to identify patterns of unauthorized access or misuse. Use these logs to conduct regular audits and enforce access policies.
  6. Integrate with Monitoring Tools: Integrate the Shared Folders tool with AWS CloudWatch Logs or similar monitoring tools to automate alerts and responses for unauthorized access or suspicious activities.

reference.name: User sessions and open files

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Data loss due to lack of backups
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data loss due to lack of backups occurs when critical data stored on AWS FSx for Windows File Server is not regularly backed up. This makes the file system vulnerable to accidental deletions, corruption, ransomware attacks, or hardware failures, potentially resulting in irrecoverable data loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Human errors, malicious insiders, cyber attackers, hardware failures.
  • Attack Vectors: Accidental deletion, data corruption, ransomware encryption, and lack of automated backup policies.

Impacts

  • Data Availability: Loss of critical files leading to operational downtime.
  • Financial Impact: Costs of data recovery or productivity losses.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from clients or stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An employee accidentally deletes key data, and without backups, it is irretrievable, causing operational delays.
  2. A ransomware attack encrypts the FSx file system, and with no recent backups, data cannot be restored without paying the ransom.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unmonitored active sessions and open files
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored active sessions and open files refer to the lack of visibility into ongoing user activities on AWS FSx for Windows File Server. Without monitoring, unauthorized or prolonged access to files may go undetected, leading to potential data breaches, misuse of sensitive data, or resource exhaustion. Effective monitoring helps detect suspicious activities and manage resources effectively, ensuring data security and operational efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Prolonged open sessions by unauthorized users due to lack of monitoring.
    • Access to sensitive files without detection, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
    • Exploiting unmonitored sessions to perform malicious actions unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data files.
  • Integrity: Potential for unauthorized modification or deletion of files.
  • Availability: Degradation of file system performance due to resource exhaustion from prolonged open sessions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: A malicious insider keeps a session open for an extended period to access and exfiltrate sensitive files. Without monitoring, this activity goes undetected, resulting in a data breach.
  2. Scenario 2: An unauthorized user gains access to the FSx file system and keeps files open without detection, preventing legitimate users from accessing or modifying the files and potentially causing system performance issues.

threat.name: Improper network security configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper network security configuration refers to inadequate or misconfigured network settings for AWS FSx for Windows File Server, which can expose the file system to unauthorized access, attacks, or data breaches. Without proper network security measures, such as restrictive security groups, network access control lists (ACLs), and Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) configurations, the file system is vulnerable to both internal and external threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cyber attackers, malicious insiders, unauthorized network users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting overly permissive security group rules that allow unauthorized inbound or outbound traffic.
    • Taking advantage of misconfigured network ACLs that do not properly restrict access to sensitive resources.
    • Using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized network access to the file system.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on the file system.
  • Integrity: Potential tampering or modification of data due to unauthorized network access.
  • Availability: Disruption of file system services from network-based attacks such as Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS).

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker exploits a misconfigured security group that allows unrestricted access from the internet to the FSx file system, enabling unauthorized data access or tampering.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider uses overly permissive network ACLs to access and manipulate sensitive files stored in the FSx file system, bypassing intended security controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - T0841 - Network Service Scanning

threat.name: Data breach due to unencrypted data
threat.desc:
A data breach due to unencrypted data occurs when sensitive information on AWS FSx for Windows File Server is not encrypted, making it vulnerable to unauthorized access or exposure. Without encryption, both data at rest and in transit can be intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to data theft or loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Interception of unencrypted data transmitted over networks.
    • Accessing unencrypted data stored on the file system through compromised credentials or inadequate access controls.
    • Exploiting system vulnerabilities to directly access unencrypted data.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data, such as personal or financial information.
  • Compliance: Breaches of regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) due to unprotected data.
  • Reputation: Damage to trust and credibility with customers and partners.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted data being transmitted between the FSx file system and an application, obtaining sensitive customer information.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider with access to the FSx file system extracts unencrypted files containing confidential business data and shares them with competitors.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to file systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to file systems occurs when users or entities gain access to AWS FSx for Windows File Server without proper authorization. This can lead to unauthorized data access, modification, or deletion, potentially resulting in data breaches, data corruption, or loss of sensitive information. Ensuring that only authorized users can access and modify the file systems is critical to maintaining data security and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting weak access controls or misconfigured permissions.
    • Using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized access.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in the FSx file system or related network configurations to bypass security measures.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Unauthorized modification or deletion of data, leading to data corruption or loss.
  • Compliance: Violation of data protection regulations if unauthorized access is not properly controlled.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An external attacker uses stolen credentials to access the FSx file system, downloading confidential files and exposing sensitive business information.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider with elevated permissions accesses restricted directories on the FSx file system and modifies or deletes critical data, disrupting business operations.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Security risks from inadequate directory integration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate directory integration in AWS FSx for Windows File Server can lead to security gaps in user authentication and access control. Without proper integration with Active Directory (AD) or other directory services, it becomes difficult to enforce consistent access policies, track user activities, and prevent unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors: Weak AD integration, misconfigured or absent access controls, insecure synchronization between AD and FSx.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Risk of unauthorized users accessing sensitive data.
  • Data Integrity: Improper access could lead to data manipulation or deletion.
  • Compliance: Potential for regulatory violations due to weak access control.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured AD integration allows unauthorized access to confidential files.
  2. An attacker intercepts weak AD synchronization to gain access to sensitive data.
  3. Outdated group policies in directory services grant excessive permissions to users.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unrecoverable data changes
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrecoverable Data Changes occur when critical data stored in AWS FSx for Windows File Server is altered or deleted without proper backup or recovery mechanisms in place. This can lead to permanent data loss, especially if changes are made by unauthorized users or malicious actors. Without version control, snapshots, or backups, the system is unable to restore the original state of the data, leading to potential operational and financial consequences.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, accidental user actions.
  • Attack Vectors: Lack of versioning, insufficient backups, accidental deletions, or deliberate tampering with critical files that are not recoverable due to the absence of data redundancy or protection mechanisms.

Impacts

  • Permanent Data Loss: Critical data is irreversibly altered or deleted, leading to unrecoverable loss.
  • Operational Disruptions: The inability to restore essential data may halt business operations or cause service outages.
  • Financial and Reputational Damage: Permanent data loss can lead to financial losses, legal penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A malicious insider deliberately deletes important project files. Without backups or snapshots, the data cannot be restored, leading to project delays and financial losses.
  2. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the file server and corrupts key files. The corruption goes unnoticed until backups are outdated, and the original files cannot be recovered.
  3. A user accidentally overwrites sensitive financial records. Without a versioning system in place, the changes are permanent, and the original records are lost.

threat.name: Compromised data integrity due to unmonitored access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored access to AWS FSx for Windows File Server can lead to data integrity compromises, where unauthorized changes to files go undetected. Without proper monitoring and logging of user access and file activities, malicious actors or insiders can modify, delete, or corrupt critical data without being discovered, resulting in data integrity issues and operational risks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Lack of monitoring tools, absence of access logs, and weak access control policies allow attackers or unauthorized users to manipulate files undetected.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity Loss: Unauthorized users can modify or delete critical files, leading to inaccurate or corrupted data.
  • Operational Disruption: Data corruption or loss can cause disruptions in workflows and services dependent on the data.
  • Compliance Issues: Failure to monitor access and ensure data integrity may lead to violations of data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A malicious insider gains access to critical financial records and alters the data, causing inaccuracies that are not noticed due to the lack of monitoring and access logging.
  2. An external attacker compromises a user account and modifies files on the server. Without active monitoring, these changes go unnoticed, leading to significant data corruption.
  3. A user accidentally deletes sensitive data, and since file access is not tracked, the deletion cannot be traced or quickly remediated.

component.name: AWS FSx for Windows File Server

weakness.name: CWE-1039
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1039: Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.

weakness.name: CWE-1120
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1120: Excessive Code Complexity The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined, quantitative measure.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-688
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-688: Function Call With Incorrect Variable or Reference as Argument The product calls a function, procedure, or routine, but the caller specifies the wrong variable or reference as one of the arguments, which may lead to undefined behavior and resultant weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Activate file access auditing for FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Enable file access auditing on AWS FSx for Windows File Server to log all access and modifications to files and folders. Use these logs to monitor user activities, detect unauthorized access attempts, and identify any unauthorized changes to sensitive data.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable Auditing: In the FSx for Windows File Server settings, activate auditing for file and folder access. Ensure that auditing covers both successful and failed access attempts to provide comprehensive monitoring.
  2. Configure Audit Policies: Set up audit policies to log specific actions, such as read, write, delete, or modify operations on sensitive files and directories.
  3. Store and Secure Logs: Ensure that audit logs are securely stored and protected against tampering. Use AWS CloudWatch Logs or a similar service to centralize log storage and ensure log integrity.
  4. Monitor and Review Logs: Regularly review audit logs to identify any unauthorized access attempts or suspicious activities. Set up alerts for specific events or patterns indicating potential security incidents.
  5. Respond to Incidents: Develop and implement procedures for responding to detected unauthorized access or changes, including escalation paths and remediation actions.

reference.name: Managing file access auditing

countermeasure.name: Configure VPC security groups and network ACLs for FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Set up Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to restrict network traffic to and from AWS FSx for Windows File Server. Ensure only the necessary ports are open for required services, and limit access to specific IP ranges or instances to prevent unauthorized access and protect the file system from potential threats.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Define Security Groups: Create and configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic for the FSx file system. Allow only essential ports (e.g., SMB port 445) and restrict traffic to trusted IP addresses or VPCs.
  2. Set Up Network ACLs: Implement network ACLs at the subnet level to provide an additional layer of security. Define rules to allow or deny specific types of traffic based on IP addresses, protocols, and port numbers, ensuring only authorized traffic reaches the FSx file system.
  3. Restrict Access to Specific IP Ranges: Configure security groups and network ACLs to limit access to the FSx file system from specific IP ranges or VPCs, preventing unauthorized access from external or untrusted networks.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Rules: Periodically review and update security group and network ACL rules to adapt to changing network requirements or security policies. Remove any unnecessary or overly permissive rules to maintain a strong security posture.
  5. Monitor Network Traffic: Use AWS CloudWatch and VPC Flow Logs to monitor network traffic to and from the FSx file system. Set up alerts for any unusual or unauthorized traffic patterns to quickly detect and respond to potential security incidents.

reference.name: File System Access Control with Amazon VPC

countermeasure.name: Enable automatic backups for FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Set up automatic backups for AWS FSx for Windows File Server to protect data against accidental deletion, corruption, or loss. Configure the backup schedule based on business requirements and define a retention period that aligns with your data retention policies.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Configure Automatic Backups: In the AWS FSx console, enable automatic backups and set the desired backup frequency (e.g., daily, weekly).
  2. Set Retention Period: Define how long backups should be retained according to business and compliance needs.
  3. Test Backups: Regularly test the backup and restore process to ensure data recovery is reliable and effective.
  4. Monitor Backup Jobs: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor backups and receive alerts for any failures.

reference.name: Protecting your data with backups

countermeasure.name: Enable shadow copies for FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Enable shadow copies on AWS FSx for Windows File Server to create point-in-time snapshots of your data. This feature allows users to recover previous versions of files and folders in case of unintended modifications, deletions, or corruption, minimizing data loss and improving data recovery capabilities.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Access the FSx Console: Navigate to the AWS Management Console and go to the FSx for Windows File Server section.
  2. Enable Shadow Copies: In the file system settings, enable the shadow copies feature for the desired volumes. Configure the frequency of snapshots based on data change rates and recovery requirements.
  3. Configure Storage and Retention: Determine the storage space allocated for shadow copies and set retention policies to balance storage costs and recovery needs.
  4. Educate Users: Inform users about how to restore previous versions of files using shadow copies, enhancing self-service recovery options.
  5. Monitor and Maintain: Regularly review shadow copy configurations and adjust settings as necessary to ensure optimal performance and storage utilization.

reference.name: Protecting your data with shadow copies

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest and in transit for FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure all data on AWS FSx for Windows File Server is encrypted both at rest and in transit to protect against unauthorized access. Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to encrypt data at rest, and enable SMB encryption to secure data during transmission between clients and the file server.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable Encryption at Rest: Use AWS KMS to manage encryption keys and automatically encrypt all data stored on FSx for Windows File Server.
  2. Enable SMB Encryption: Configure FSx for Windows File Server to use SMB 3.0 or higher to encrypt data in transit, ensuring all communication between clients and the server is secure.
  3. Review and Update Policies: Regularly review encryption policies to ensure compliance with security standards and regulatory requirements.

Monitor Encryption Status: Use AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail to monitor encryption status and access attempts to ensure data remains protected.

reference.name: Encryption in Transit

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Integrate FSx for Windows File Server with AWS Managed Microsoft AD
countermeasure.desc:
Integrate your AWS FSx for Windows File Server with AWS Managed Microsoft Active Directory (AD) to centralize user authentication and authorization. This integration ensures consistent access controls across your organization by leveraging existing directory services, simplifying management, and enhancing security through unified user and group management.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Set Up AWS Managed Microsoft AD: If not already configured, deploy AWS Managed Microsoft AD within your AWS environment. Ensure the directory is properly configured to support your organizational needs.
  2. Integrate FSx with Managed AD: During the creation or configuration of the FSx for Windows File Server, select the option to join the file system to your AWS Managed Microsoft AD. Provide the necessary directory information, such as the DNS name and organizational unit (OU) for computer accounts.
  3. Configure Access Controls: Use Active Directory tools, such as Group Policy and ACLs, to manage user permissions and access rights to files and folders on the FSx file system. This ensures that only authorized users can access specific resources based on their AD credentials.
  4. Enable Kerberos Authentication: Ensure Kerberos authentication is enabled for secure, seamless single sign-on (SSO) for users accessing the FSx file system, leveraging the existing AD credentials.
  5. Monitor and Audit Access: Use AWS CloudTrail and Windows Event Viewer to monitor access to the FSx file system. Set up logging and alerts for unauthorized access attempts or changes to AD user accounts or group memberships.

reference.name: Using Amazon FSx with AWS Directory Service for Microsoft Active Directory

countermeasure.name: Use Windows ACLs for fine-grained access control on FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage Windows Access Control Lists (ACLs) to enforce fine-grained file- and folder-level access controls on AWS FSx for Windows File Server. Configure ACLs to ensure that only authorized users and groups have access to specific files or directories, based on their roles and responsibilities. This control helps prevent unauthorized access, modification, or deletion of sensitive data.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Access File System Security Settings: Open the FSx for Windows File Server management console and navigate to the file or folder properties you want to secure.
  2. Configure Windows ACLs:
  3. Go to the "Security" tab and click "Edit" to modify permissions.
  4. Add or remove users and groups, specifying the level of access (e.g., read, write, modify) for each entity.
  5. Set Inheritance and Propagation: Configure inheritance and propagation settings to ensure that ACLs are correctly applied to all subfolders and files, maintaining consistent access controls.
  6. Review and Update ACLs Regularly: Periodically review ACL settings to ensure they reflect current user roles and organizational policies. Adjust permissions as needed to accommodate changes in access requirements or user roles.
  7. Monitor Access Logs: Enable auditing and use Windows Event Viewer or AWS CloudWatch to monitor access attempts and detect unauthorized access or policy violations.

reference.name: Best practices for using FSx for Windows File Server with Amazon ECS

countermeasure.name: Utilize the Shared Folders tool to monitor active sessions and open files on FSx for Windows File Server
countermeasure.desc:
Use the Shared Folders tool on AWS FSx for Windows File Server to monitor active user sessions and open files. This enables you to detect unauthorized access, manage user sessions effectively, and ensure proper resource utilization. Monitoring active sessions and open files helps prevent prolonged unauthorized access and minimizes the risk of data breaches or misuse.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Access the Shared Folders Tool: Open the Shared Folders tool on your FSx for Windows File Server through the File and Storage Services in Windows Server Manager or via Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) session.
  2. Monitor Active Sessions: Regularly check the "Sessions" tab to view currently connected users and their access details. Look for any unusual or unauthorized sessions that may indicate potential security risks.
  3. Review Open Files: Navigate to the "Open Files" tab to see all files currently in use by active sessions. Monitor for any unexpected or unauthorized access to sensitive files.
  4. Terminate Unauthorized Access: If unauthorized sessions or file accesses are detected, use the Shared Folders tool to immediately disconnect the session or close open files to prevent further access.
  5. Log and Audit Activities: Keep logs of session and file access activities to identify patterns of unauthorized access or misuse. Use these logs to conduct regular audits and enforce access policies.
  6. Integrate with Monitoring Tools: Integrate the Shared Folders tool with AWS CloudWatch Logs or similar monitoring tools to automate alerts and responses for unauthorized access or suspicious activities.

reference.name: User sessions and open files

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Data loss due to lack of backups
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data loss due to lack of backups occurs when critical data stored on AWS FSx for Windows File Server is not regularly backed up. This makes the file system vulnerable to accidental deletions, corruption, ransomware attacks, or hardware failures, potentially resulting in irrecoverable data loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Human errors, malicious insiders, cyber attackers, hardware failures.
  • Attack Vectors: Accidental deletion, data corruption, ransomware encryption, and lack of automated backup policies.

Impacts

  • Data Availability: Loss of critical files leading to operational downtime.
  • Financial Impact: Costs of data recovery or productivity losses.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from clients or stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An employee accidentally deletes key data, and without backups, it is irretrievable, causing operational delays.
  2. A ransomware attack encrypts the FSx file system, and with no recent backups, data cannot be restored without paying the ransom.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unmonitored active sessions and open files
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored active sessions and open files refer to the lack of visibility into ongoing user activities on AWS FSx for Windows File Server. Without monitoring, unauthorized or prolonged access to files may go undetected, leading to potential data breaches, misuse of sensitive data, or resource exhaustion. Effective monitoring helps detect suspicious activities and manage resources effectively, ensuring data security and operational efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Prolonged open sessions by unauthorized users due to lack of monitoring.
    • Access to sensitive files without detection, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
    • Exploiting unmonitored sessions to perform malicious actions unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data files.
  • Integrity: Potential for unauthorized modification or deletion of files.
  • Availability: Degradation of file system performance due to resource exhaustion from prolonged open sessions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: A malicious insider keeps a session open for an extended period to access and exfiltrate sensitive files. Without monitoring, this activity goes undetected, resulting in a data breach.
  2. Scenario 2: An unauthorized user gains access to the FSx file system and keeps files open without detection, preventing legitimate users from accessing or modifying the files and potentially causing system performance issues.

threat.name: Improper network security configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper network security configuration refers to inadequate or misconfigured network settings for AWS FSx for Windows File Server, which can expose the file system to unauthorized access, attacks, or data breaches. Without proper network security measures, such as restrictive security groups, network access control lists (ACLs), and Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) configurations, the file system is vulnerable to both internal and external threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cyber attackers, malicious insiders, unauthorized network users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting overly permissive security group rules that allow unauthorized inbound or outbound traffic.
    • Taking advantage of misconfigured network ACLs that do not properly restrict access to sensitive resources.
    • Using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized network access to the file system.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on the file system.
  • Integrity: Potential tampering or modification of data due to unauthorized network access.
  • Availability: Disruption of file system services from network-based attacks such as Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS).

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker exploits a misconfigured security group that allows unrestricted access from the internet to the FSx file system, enabling unauthorized data access or tampering.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider uses overly permissive network ACLs to access and manipulate sensitive files stored in the FSx file system, bypassing intended security controls.

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - T0841 - Network Service Scanning

threat.name: Data breach due to unencrypted data
threat.desc:
A data breach due to unencrypted data occurs when sensitive information on AWS FSx for Windows File Server is not encrypted, making it vulnerable to unauthorized access or exposure. Without encryption, both data at rest and in transit can be intercepted or accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to data theft or loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Interception of unencrypted data transmitted over networks.
    • Accessing unencrypted data stored on the file system through compromised credentials or inadequate access controls.
    • Exploiting system vulnerabilities to directly access unencrypted data.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data, such as personal or financial information.
  • Compliance: Breaches of regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) due to unprotected data.
  • Reputation: Damage to trust and credibility with customers and partners.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted data being transmitted between the FSx file system and an application, obtaining sensitive customer information.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider with access to the FSx file system extracts unencrypted files containing confidential business data and shares them with competitors.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to file systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to file systems occurs when users or entities gain access to AWS FSx for Windows File Server without proper authorization. This can lead to unauthorized data access, modification, or deletion, potentially resulting in data breaches, data corruption, or loss of sensitive information. Ensuring that only authorized users can access and modify the file systems is critical to maintaining data security and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting weak access controls or misconfigured permissions.
    • Using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized access.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in the FSx file system or related network configurations to bypass security measures.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Unauthorized modification or deletion of data, leading to data corruption or loss.
  • Compliance: Violation of data protection regulations if unauthorized access is not properly controlled.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An external attacker uses stolen credentials to access the FSx file system, downloading confidential files and exposing sensitive business information.
  2. Scenario 2: A malicious insider with elevated permissions accesses restricted directories on the FSx file system and modifies or deletes critical data, disrupting business operations.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Security risks from inadequate directory integration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate directory integration in AWS FSx for Windows File Server can lead to security gaps in user authentication and access control. Without proper integration with Active Directory (AD) or other directory services, it becomes difficult to enforce consistent access policies, track user activities, and prevent unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors: Weak AD integration, misconfigured or absent access controls, insecure synchronization between AD and FSx.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Risk of unauthorized users accessing sensitive data.
  • Data Integrity: Improper access could lead to data manipulation or deletion.
  • Compliance: Potential for regulatory violations due to weak access control.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured AD integration allows unauthorized access to confidential files.
  2. An attacker intercepts weak AD synchronization to gain access to sensitive data.
  3. Outdated group policies in directory services grant excessive permissions to users.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unrecoverable data changes
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrecoverable Data Changes occur when critical data stored in AWS FSx for Windows File Server is altered or deleted without proper backup or recovery mechanisms in place. This can lead to permanent data loss, especially if changes are made by unauthorized users or malicious actors. Without version control, snapshots, or backups, the system is unable to restore the original state of the data, leading to potential operational and financial consequences.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, accidental user actions.
  • Attack Vectors: Lack of versioning, insufficient backups, accidental deletions, or deliberate tampering with critical files that are not recoverable due to the absence of data redundancy or protection mechanisms.

Impacts

  • Permanent Data Loss: Critical data is irreversibly altered or deleted, leading to unrecoverable loss.
  • Operational Disruptions: The inability to restore essential data may halt business operations or cause service outages.
  • Financial and Reputational Damage: Permanent data loss can lead to financial losses, legal penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A malicious insider deliberately deletes important project files. Without backups or snapshots, the data cannot be restored, leading to project delays and financial losses.
  2. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the file server and corrupts key files. The corruption goes unnoticed until backups are outdated, and the original files cannot be recovered.
  3. A user accidentally overwrites sensitive financial records. Without a versioning system in place, the changes are permanent, and the original records are lost.

threat.name: Compromised data integrity due to unmonitored access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored access to AWS FSx for Windows File Server can lead to data integrity compromises, where unauthorized changes to files go undetected. Without proper monitoring and logging of user access and file activities, malicious actors or insiders can modify, delete, or corrupt critical data without being discovered, resulting in data integrity issues and operational risks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Lack of monitoring tools, absence of access logs, and weak access control policies allow attackers or unauthorized users to manipulate files undetected.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity Loss: Unauthorized users can modify or delete critical files, leading to inaccurate or corrupted data.
  • Operational Disruption: Data corruption or loss can cause disruptions in workflows and services dependent on the data.
  • Compliance Issues: Failure to monitor access and ensure data integrity may lead to violations of data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A malicious insider gains access to critical financial records and alters the data, causing inaccuracies that are not noticed due to the lack of monitoring and access logging.
  2. An external attacker compromises a user account and modifies files on the server. Without active monitoring, these changes go unnoticed, leading to significant data corruption.
  3. A user accidentally deletes sensitive data, and since file access is not tracked, the deletion cannot be traced or quickly remediated.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure security groups for NAT Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS NAT Gateway, it is crucial to apply appropriate security group rules to manage both inbound and outbound traffic effectively. A well-defined set of security group rules ensures that only legitimate traffic is allowed to communicate with your NAT Gateway, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches. Follow the steps below to implement the control:

1. Create a Security Group for your NAT Gateway:

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, choose Security Groups.
  • Choose Create security group.
  • Provide a name and description for the security group and select the VPC in which your NAT Gateway resides.

2. Define Inbound Rules:

  • By default, the NAT Gateway does not require any inbound rules as it is designed to handle outbound traffic for instances in private subnets.
  • However, if there are specific requirements to allow certain types of inbound traffic, add rules to permit only the necessary traffic from trustable sources.

3. Define Outbound Rules:

  • Specify outbound rules to allow the types of traffic needed by the instances using the NAT Gateway. Typically, you would permit HTTP(S) traffic, specific service ports, or any stateful connections necessary for your applications:
    • HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443) traffic to the Internet.
    • Specific ports for other services (e.g., port 123 for NTP, port 25 for SMTP).
    • Restrict outbound traffic by specifying destination IP ranges and port numbers as per your security policy.

4. Attach the Security Group to the NAT Gateway:

  • In the Amazon VPC console, go to Network Interfaces.
  • Find the network interface associated with your NAT Gateway (usually named with "nat" in the description).
  • Edit the security groups associated with that network interface and attach the newly created security group.

Regularly review and update the security group rules to adapt to any changes in your application's requirements or to address newly identified security threats. For detailed guidelines, refer to the AWS documentation: Security Groups for Your VPC.

Ensure to follow the best practices and recommendations outlined in the NAT Gateway documentation for optimal security, which can be found here: AWS NAT Gateway Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC Flow Logs
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and monitoring capabilities of your VPC, setting up VPC Flow Logs to capture information about IP traffic going to and from network interfaces is crucial. Implementing this countermeasure enables you to gain deeper visibility into network traffic patterns, identify potential threats, and troubleshoot network connectivity issues effectively.

Here's a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer to set up VPC Flow Logs:

  1. Navigate to the Amazon VPC Console:
    • Open the Amazon VPC console.
  2. Choose Your VPC:
    • From the navigation pane, select Flow Logs.
    • Click Create flow log.
  3. Configure Log Destination:
    • For Filter, select the required traffic type (All, Reject, or Accept).
    • For Destination, choose where you want the flow log to be stored (e.g., Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon S3).
  4. Specify Log Group or S3 Bucket:
    • If you select CloudWatch Logs, choose an existing log group or create a new one.
    • If you select S3, enter the ARN of the S3 bucket.
  5. Set IAM Role:
    • Make sure you have an IAM role that allows the VPC to publish flow logs to the chosen destination.
    • If needed, create a new role or attach policies to an existing role.
  6. Review and Create:
    • Review the settings and click Create flow log.

For additional guidance on VPC Flow Logs configuration, refer to the official AWS documentation: VPC Flow Logs Documentation

Implementing this countermeasure effectively will fortify the security posture of your AWS NAT Gateway by allowing comprehensive monitoring and analysis of IP traffic within your VPC.

standard.ref: SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

customField.value: SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

countermeasure.name: Set up route tables accordingly
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that traffic within your VPC is correctly routed through the AWS NAT Gateway for security purposes, it is essential to configure your route tables properly. This countermeasure leverages the robust security features provided by the AWS NAT Gateway to facilitate secure outbound internet connectivity for instances in your private subnet, while preventing inbound connections initiated from the internet.

Steps to Configure Route Tables

  • Create a NAT Gateway:

In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the VPC dashboard. Under the Nat Gateway section, create a new NAT Gateway in your selected public subnet. Make sure to associate an Elastic IP Address with this NAT Gateway.

Refer to the official documentation for detailed steps: Create a NAT Gateway.

  • Modify Route Tables:

Locate the route table associated with the private subnet that requires outbound internet access. Edit the route table and add a new route. The destination CIDR block should be 0.0.0.0/0, and the target should be the NAT Gateway created in the previous step.

Refer to the official documentation for route table configuration details: Work with Route Tables.

Security Considerations

Configuring your route tables correctly ensures that instances in private subnets do not have a direct path to the internet. Instead, all outbound traffic is routed through the NAT Gateway, which manages the initiation of outbound sessions and blocks unsolicited inbound traffic. This configuration enhances the security posture of your VPC by limiting exposure to potential threats from the internet.

For comprehensive security guidelines on using AWS NAT Gateway, please refer to the official documentation: AWS NAT Gateway Security Guidance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to NAT gateway
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthenticated users may gain access to the NAT Gateway, potentially leading to unapproved network traffic and data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the NAT Gateway setup.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to network resources, data breaches, data exfiltration, and potentially significant operational disruptions and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfigured security group that allows unrestricted access to the NAT Gateway, gaining the ability to send and receive unauthorized traffic through the gateway. Another scenario might involve an internal employee abusing incorrectly set permissions to access sensitive data or systems not meant for their role.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of NAT gateway traffic
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of monitoring for the traffic passing through the NAT Gateway can lead to undetected malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors exploiting the absence of monitoring mechanisms may initiate various types of attacks such as data exfiltration, command and control communication, or other malicious activities.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, compliance violations, financial losses, reputational damage, and compromised cloud resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker compromises an EC2 instance within the private subnet and uses the NAT Gateway to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. Another scenario might involve malware on compromised instances communicating with a malicious command and control server through the NAT Gateway, leading to further exploitation and lateral movement within the cloud environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

threat.name: Data leakage via misconfigured route tables
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured route tables can result in sensitive traffic being directed through non-secure paths, which increases the risk of data leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include internal users or automated scripts that incorrectly configure route tables, as well as malicious insiders or attackers who exploit the misconfiguration to redirect traffic.
Impacts
The impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data leakage, potential data manipulation, and exposure of the organization to compliance and regulatory penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS environment and modifies the route tables to redirect traffic through a non-secure path, capturing sensitive information. Alternatively, an internal user misconfigures the route tables, resulting in the exposure of data to the internet or an insecure network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1602 - Data from Configuration Repository

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Control traffic using network ACLs
countermeasure.desc: Manage inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level by configuring network Access Control Lists (ACLs) in your VPC. Network ACLs act as stateless firewalls for your subnets, allowing you to set rules that permit or deny traffic based on IP protocol, port number, and source/destination IP address. To implement this, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, create or modify network ACLs, and associate them with the appropriate subnets. Regularly review and update ACL rules to enhance security and compliance.

countermeasure.name: Detect potential threats with Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Enable Amazon GuardDuty to continuously monitor VPC flow logs for malicious activity and potential security threats. GuardDuty uses machine learning and threat intelligence to analyze traffic patterns and detect anomalies. To implement this, activate GuardDuty in the AWS Management Console, configure it to ingest VPC flow logs, DNS logs, and CloudTrail event logs. Regularly review GuardDuty findings and take appropriate actions to mitigate identified threats, ensuring your VPC remains secure against evolving attack vectors.

countermeasure.name: Distribute subnets across multiple availability zones
countermeasure.desc: To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and scalability of your applications hosted on Amazon VPC, create subnets in multiple Availability Zones (AZs) within the same AWS Region. An Availability Zone comprises one or more data centers with independent power, networking, and connectivity. By distributing subnets across multiple AZs, you can mitigate the risk of a single point of failure and enhance the resilience of your application against potential outages or failures in a single AZ. This approach provides redundancy and improves overall system reliability.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement VPC flow logs to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within your VPC. This log data can help you monitor network traffic, identify potential security threats, diagnose network issues, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. To enable VPC Flow Logs, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, select your VPC, and create a new Flow Log, specifying the destination for the log data, such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs or an S3 bucket. Regularly review and analyze these logs for abnormal traffic patterns and security incidents.

Review findings to address any unintended access, ensuring robust network security.

AWS Network Firewall provides stateful, managed network firewall and intrusion prevention services to safeguard your VPC from malicious activity. To implement it, create a firewall in the AWS Management Console, configure rules to control inbound and outbound traffic, and associate the firewall with your VPC subnets. Regularly update and monitor these rules to ensure they align with your security policies and threat landscape.

Regularly review and update IAM policies to maintain security best practices and compliance.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single point of failure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A Single Point of Failure (SPOF) refers to a critical component or node within a system whose failure can cause the entire system to stop functioning. In a cloud environment like Amazon VPS, this can result from configuring all resources within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leading to potential outages if that zone experiences issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Natural disasters affecting a specific AZ.
  • Technical failures such as power outages, network issues, or hardware malfunctions within the AZ.
  • Cyberattacks targeting the infrastructure of a specific AZ.

Impacts

  • Downtime and service disruptions.
  • Loss of availability for applications and services.
  • Potential data loss or corruption.
  • Financial losses due to service outages and recovery costs.
  • Reputational damage due to service unreliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster: A severe storm impacts the data center in a single AZ, causing all services hosted in that zone to become unavailable.
  2. Technical Failure: A power outage in the data center leads to downtime for all resources configured solely in that AZ.
  3. Cyberattack: A targeted DDoS attack overwhelms the infrastructure of a single AZ, resulting in service disruption for all resources within that zone.

To mitigate this threat, it is recommended to distribute resources across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring redundancy and high availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized network access occurs when individuals or entities gain access to a network without permission, potentially leading to data breaches, service disruption, and exploitation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers using methods such as brute force or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors exploiting legitimate access.
  • Misconfigurations in security settings, such as overly permissive security groups or network ACLs.

Impacts

  • Data theft and loss of sensitive information.
  • Service disruptions and potential downtime.
  • Increased risk of further network and system exploitation.
  • Financial losses and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: A hacker gains unauthorized access to an EC2 instance by exploiting a vulnerability in a web application and subsequently accessing the underlying network.
  2. Internal Misuse: An employee uses their legitimate access to explore unauthorized network segments, leading to potential data exfiltration.
  3. Misconfiguration: A misconfigured security group allows inbound traffic from any IP address, enabling an attacker to exploit services running within the VPC.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strict access controls using security groups and network ACLs, regularly review and update security configurations, and employ network monitoring tools to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring refers to the lack of adequate surveillance and tracking mechanisms to detect, log, and analyze activities within a system. In Amazon VPS, this can lead to undetected security incidents, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Hackers exploiting unmonitored vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors taking advantage of weak logging practices.
  • Unintended configuration changes going unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Delayed or missed detection of security breaches.
  • Increased risk of data theft or corruption.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Prolonged downtime and extended incident response times.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Data Breach: A hacker gains unauthorized access to a VPS due to a missed security patch, which goes unnoticed due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. Internal Threat: An employee with elevated privileges accesses sensitive data without proper logging, making it difficult to trace the action.
  3. Configuration Error: Misconfigurations in security groups or network ACLs are not detected, leading to potential exposure of resources.

To address this threat, it is crucial to implement comprehensive monitoring solutions like AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail, and to regularly review and analyze logs to identify and respond to potential security incidents promptly.

threat.name: Unintended network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unintended network access occurs when resources within a network are inadvertently exposed to unauthorized entities due to misconfigurations or oversight, leading to potential data breaches, unauthorized modifications, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting exposed services.
  • Internal users accessing unintended resources due to misconfigured permissions.
  • Automated scripts or tools scanning for open ports and services.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Service disruptions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation and lateral movement within the network.
  • Financial and reputational damage due to data breaches and service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exposed Services: A database is unintentionally left accessible from the internet due to misconfigured security groups, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  2. Internal Access: An employee accesses confidential files stored in an improperly secured S3 bucket that should have been restricted.
  3. Automated Scans: An automated tool finds an open management port on an EC2 instance, which is then exploited to gain unauthorized access.

To mitigate this threat, regularly review and update security group rules, network ACLs, and use tools like AWS Network Access Analyzer to identify and rectify unintended network exposures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Unfiltered traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unfiltered traffic refers to network traffic that is not adequately controlled or monitored, allowing potentially harmful data to enter or exit the network unchecked. This can lead to security vulnerabilities, data breaches, and network inefficiencies in an Amazon VPS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers sending malicious data packets.
  • Internal users inadvertently or deliberately bypassing security measures.
  • Misconfigured security groups and network ACLs allowing all traffic.

Impacts

  • Exposure to malware and other malicious content.
  • Data exfiltration or loss of sensitive information.
  • Network congestion and reduced performance.
  • Increased risk of further network exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malware Infiltration: An attacker sends malicious traffic that goes unchecked into the network, infecting servers and spreading malware.
  2. Data Exfiltration: An internal user sends sensitive data out of the network due to lack of outbound traffic filtering.
  3. DoS Attack: Unfiltered inbound traffic leads to a Denial of Service attack, overwhelming the network and causing service outages.

To mitigate this threat, implement and regularly update security groups, network ACLs, and use AWS Network Firewall to filter and monitor inbound and outbound traffic.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised IAM credentials
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Compromised IAM (Identity and Access Management) credentials refer to instances where attackers gain unauthorized access to AWS resources by obtaining valid IAM credentials. This can lead to significant security breaches, unauthorized data access, and control over AWS services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishing attacks to trick users into revealing credentials.
  • Brute force attacks to guess passwords.
  • Exploitation of weak password policies.
  • Insider threats where employees misuse access privileges.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Potential data breaches and data loss.
  • Unauthorized modifications or deletions of resources.
  • Financial losses due to misuse of AWS services.
  • Reputational damage from security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phishing Attack: An attacker sends a phishing email to an employee, tricking them into providing their IAM credentials, which are then used to access and extract data from S3 buckets.
  2. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt logins until they successfully guess a weak password, gaining unauthorized access to critical resources.
  3. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their IAM credentials to access sensitive information and leak it to external parties.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strong password policies, enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all IAM users, regularly rotate credentials, and monitor IAM activities using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config for unusual access patterns.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege security groups
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize attack surface and prevent unauthorized access, restrict Security Group rules to only the ports, protocols, and source CIDRs your workload requires. This ensures that only legitimate traffic can reach your instances, reducing risk of compromise or lateral movement within your VPC.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify required traffic: Document exactly which ports, protocols, and IP ranges your application needs for inbound and outbound communication.
  2. Tighten Security Group rules: Update each Security Group so that inbound and outbound rules specify only those required ports and source/destination CIDRsavoid using 0.0.0.0/0 or ::/0 unless absolutely necessary.
  3. Use security group references: Where possible, reference other Security Groups instead of IP ranges to scope access to known AWS resources.
  4. Automate enforcement: Deploy AWS Config managed rulerestricted-security-groups (or a custom rule) to continuously detect overly permissive rules, and incorporate rule checks into your IaC templates (CloudFormation, Terraform).
  5. Review and audit regularly: Schedule periodic reviews of all Security Group rules to ensure they remain aligned with current application requirements and remove any stale or unused rules.

References:

  • Control traffic to your AWS resources using security groups

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Shield
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your subnet resources from volumetric and applicationlayer denialofservice (DDoS) attacks, implement AWS Shield to automatically detect and mitigate malicious traffic. This ensures high availability by absorbing or blocking attack traffic before it impacts your instances.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable AWS Shield Standard: Shield Standard is enabled by default at no extra cost for all AWS customers confirm coverage for your Elastic IPs, Application Load Balancers, and CloudFront distributions.
  2. Subscribe to AWS Shield Advanced (optional): For enhanced protection, enable Shield Advanced in the AWS Shield console, choose the resources (Elastic IPs, ALBs, NLBs, Global Accelerators) you want to protect, and accept the service terms.
  3. Configure DDoS response settings: If using Shield Advanced, grant AWS DDoS Response Team (DRT) access to your account for emergency assistance, and set up proactive notifications.
  4. Monitor metrics and alarms: Use CloudWatch metrics (e.g.,DDoSDetected, AttackVolume) to track attack activity and create alarms to trigger automated responses (AWS WAF ratebased rules, autoscaling actions).
  5. Review protection reports: Regularly review Shield Advanced attack diagnostics and cost protection reports to validate coverage and adjust resource configurations as needed.

References:

  • AWS Shield Advanced API Reference

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Restrict outbound traffic
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthorized data exfiltration and reduce risk of communicating with malicious endpoints, restrict subnet egress traffic to only approved destinations using Network ACL outbound rules and AWS PrivateLink.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Define approved destinations: Create a whitelist of trusted external IP ranges, domains, and AWS service endpoints required by your workloads.
  2. Configure Network ACL outbound rules: In each subnets NACL, add explicit ALLOW rules for only the approved IP addresses and ports. Set a final DENY rule (0.0.0.0/0) to block all other egress traffic.
  3. Use AWS PrivateLink for AWS services: Replace direct internet access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, etc.) with PrivateLink endpoints to keep traffic on the AWS network and avoid exposure to the public internet.
  4. Validate with AWS Config: Enable the managed rulenetwork-acl-traffic-check (or a custom rule) to detect overly permissive outbound rules.
  5. Monitor and audit: Regularly review VPC Flow Logs for denied egress attempts and update NACL rules or PrivateLink endpoints as application requirements evolve.

References:

  • Control subnet traffic with network access control lists

countermeasure.name: Restrict subnet routing
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent resources in private subnets from being directly reachable fromor reachingthe public internet by removing any 0.0.0.0/0 route to an Internet Gateway in their route tables and disabling automatic assignment of public IPv4 addresses. This reduces exposure of sensitive workloads and enforces a clear separation between public and private network tiers.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Identify all subnets designated as private in your VPC.
  2. For each private subnets route table, verify there is no route entry with destination 0.0.0.0/0 (or ::/0) pointing to an Internet Gateway (igw*). Remove any such routes if present.
  3. In the AWS Console or via IaC (CloudFormation/Terraform), disable Auto-assign public IPv4 address for each private subnet.
  4. Deploy the AWS Config managed rulevpc-no-public-ip (CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark 4.1) to continuously check that private subnets do not autoassign public IPs.
  5. Schedule periodic audits of subnet route tables and subnet settings to ensure no drift from this configuration.

References:

  • How Amazon VPC works

standard.ref: Information security for use of cloud services
Infrastructure and Virtualization Security Policy and Procedures
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(7)
